pros: Lots of opportunities, 2-week period at the start of the year closed for financial aid receiving applicants, a lot of jobs where you can learn valuable skills as well as a lot of jobs where you can get paid to sit around for 4 hours doing homework (last one could be a pro or a con, depending on who you are)
cons: The pay is not that great, though for a work study job I guess it's fine. For a place like Middlebury you'd expect wages to be higher, but I guess they make up for it by having so many on-campus jobs available. If you want one & go after it, you're pretty much guaranteed to find one. A lot of the jobs can be kind of boring - sitting at a front desk and doing homework for 75% of your time (lib, fin. aid, mail center, etc) which could be either good or bad depending on what you want.

review_title: Great, small, graduate-focused institution of higher ed
pros: I worked at MIIS as a research assistant during my two years as a master's student and was recruited to come back after graduation as a full-time employee of an on-campus research center. Most of the degree programs pay their student employees quite fairly, and the salary and benefits structure for regular employees is competitive with or better than other peer academic institutions. The location and climate in Monterey cannot be beat. The school is small (700 students from 40 countries, all earning master's degrees) and the administration is enlightened and responsive.
cons: Many research centers are dependent on grants or donations for funding, which waxes and wanes. Monterey is not a bustling metropolis like San Francisco, but rather is well-suited for those that love surfing, hiking and a more relaxed California pace of life.

review_title: "Mom & Pop" shop that thinks it is a global organization
job_title: Enrollment Marketing Manager in Monterey, CA
pros:
Beautiful location. Quiet, provincial seaside town. Easy commute. Good job for a recent graduate who desires exposure to many areas of higher ed.
The Monterey Institute struggled financially a few years ago, but Middlebury College acquired it recently and injected much needed money and organizational expertise.
cons: MIIS is run like a small-town "mom & pop" organization.  It lacks certain fundamental organizational systems, and compensates for this by placing an overabundance of authority in the hands of a very small number of long-term employees - many former graduates. New hires from the outside rarely stay more than a couple of years before moving on to higher paid positions elsewhere.

review_title: Good place to work but be ware of siloed departments
pros: Definitely full of good people that enjoy their work and sharing what they know with anyone who is curious. Everyone is passionate about the international related goals of the school.
cons: People are quite siloed into their particular departments, and there can be quite a bit of resistance to cross sectional collaboration at times. Sometimes this results in wasted project conception time, because no one wants to piggyback on the efforts of an existing plan at times

review_title: Middlebury College provides a collegial environment that is conducive to teaching, learning, and dialogue.
pros: Middlebury is a caring community with a collegial work environment. The administration does a good job treating employees with respect. Most of the students are very bright, respectful, and motivated. The college's financial health is better than that of most small liberal arts colleges.
cons: It's unclear how faculty pay raises are determined. Rather than allowing faculty to apply for open positions in the administration, the current administration quietly selects new administrators. The college is located in a remote area with long, cold winters.

review_title: Love the place, but hate the pay.
pros: The students, who come from all over the world with enriching life experiences.  All of the American students have lived, traveled, studied or worked overseas, and must have a strong facility in at least one other language.
cons: Cost of living on the Central Coast is _expensive_!  The cost of housing is still prohibitive, even rents are still too high in this recessionary market, perhaps because the Defense Language Institute and Naval Postgraduate School subsidize housing for their students, and they keep expanding their enrollment.  This puts upward pressure on rents throughout the area.

review_title: A great place to work if you're in the right field
pros: Most students are highly motivated and most faculty are helpful and have strong professional backgrounds. Advising and placement office work hard to help students launch their careers. Development staff work well with faculty and search diligently for new donors.
cons: Performance review process, especially for adjunct faculty, needs a serious overhaul. Salaries are a little low for an area with very high cost of living. Too much emphasis on branding and not enough on recruiting and retaining top talent or highest qualified students.

review_title: Unique international experience in a historical Californian place.
pros: The Institute is a small-sized place where you can immerse yourself into a current of the issues of global importance. Without the need of going overseas, you can learn from and about different cultures in one place.
cons: The Institute has many awesome ideas; however, the funding to realize those creative and impactful ideas is not always suffiecient.

review_title: I like the collegiate environment here and the ability to work with other students as a student employee.
pros:
Not very demanding jobs, including mine at the college's recycling center facility. Many of the jobs, including the ones in the library, allow students to do homework while on the job, which is nice.
I hear that at the Technology Helpdesk, or more research-focused jobs, you can actually learn something from your job and use those applicable skills on your resume while applying for internships and jobs down the road.
cons: Low hourly pay compared to other elite colleges and universities

review_title: ADMISSIONS OFFICE: Good college job for a couple reasons
pros:
-Good experience in sales if you can land a higher-touch tour guide role
-As good as it gets pay-wise at Midd
-Office experience, for better and worse
cons:
-Most of the lower-level staff are entrenched in the upkeep of their own roles and systems rather than the big picture
-Job critique and supervision comes from someone who has not experienced the students' jobs or needs

review_title: Pockets of passionate, amazing people, drowning in bureaucracy and an administration looking towards getting out
pros: Some smart, worldly staff, faculty, and students, excited by innovation, changing the world, and learning
cons: Pride & politics unfit for boutique institution, admin doesn't care about students, staff comprised of alumns, embarrassing admissions rates

review_title: Good opportunities for students who want to make money
job_title: IM Sports Commissioner in Middlebury, VT
pros: The college does a great job of making sure you can balance work and school. You can usually find hours that fit around your class schedule and extracurriculars. It also offers great work-study opportunities.
cons: The jobs can take a lot of time out of your week, as school is very demanding. The pay for the more menial jobs is great, but the pay for the harder, more skilled/demanding jobs is marginally better. That's frustrating.

job_title: Business & Financial Operations Analyst in Middlebury, VT
pros:
- Great work-life balance
- Decent benefits
- A paid week off between Christmas and New Years every year
- Beautiful campus
- Work hour flexibility (at least in my department)
- College president is very down-to-earth, friendly, welcoming

cons:

- Not adequate work space
- Pay grade is mediocre and there are no raises
- The growth opportunities are fairly minimal

job_title: Counselor, Middlebury-Monterey Language Academy in Middlebury, VT
pros: This program was a huge learning experience to be a part of. It was a lot of work, but it was amazing to watch the students learn.
cons: In its first year, things were a little difficult but I assume procedures are now set in place that help the program run more smoothly.

pros: Beautiful campus, ambitious and intelligent students, good health insurance, flexible vacation time, generous training opportunities
cons: Dysfunctional management, lots of in-fighting among managers, lower than average pay (for the industry), lack of upward mobility

pros: Open environment, great package, wonderful people, amazing location, excellent facilities, great summer vibe and excellent opportunities to become exposed to various cultures
cons: Cold winters, recent cost reductions, not much time for development or emphasis on growth. Long term staff rewarded far better than new staff.

pros: Fairly easy to get jobs on campus as student, professors and students have very open communication
cons: It can become very difficult to maintain a balance between working on your own projects and maintaining work hours. Middlebury can be intense.

pros: Great colleagues passionate about their work.  Engaged student body.  Middlebury takes good care of their employees and is an inspiring place to work.
cons: As with the majority of academic institutions, there's some bureaucracy that slows things down.  Overall there aren't many cons, though.

review_title: One of the most negative experiences of my life
job_title: Tutor Assistant, ESL in Monterey, CA
pros: Wonderful, diverse groups of students, office is quaint and relaxing
cons:
My former coworkers and successors agree--despite this being a small school facility, it's highly disorganized. It "fits together like a jigsaw puzzle with a couple of pieces gone."

You will be blamed when things go wrong. There is nothing you can do. This is a dysfunctional toxic environment. The low salary and possibility of getting a low-paid teaching gig after graduating with a degree does not make up for the abuse nor dysfunction.

review_title: A small, intimate organization: Some good working conditions, but beware
pros:
* Small, pleasant campus in a near-idyllic location; low-key campus atmosphere
• Most students, faculty, and staff are genuinely committed global concerns
• Interesting international student population
• Faculty & staff compensation & benefits competitive (when compared to higher ed institutions, anyway)
cons: For an institution that touts its "Be the Solution" tagline, this place suffers from quite a few serious problems with its leadership and policies. Admin staff are made up mainly of yes-men and yes-women who answer directly to Middlebury and whose actual leadership credentials are questionable at best: Their priorities seem to be traveling all the time (presumably to raise funds and recruit students) - not actually providing leadership. Policy-making is a wholly top-down "process" that has recently involved nothing but a pretense of shared responsibility. There is really no accountability where admin staff are concerned - they get away with arbitrary decisions, unfairness, and incompetence but never seem to get challenged or sanctioned. Favoritism in hiring, retention, and promotion is the norm, with alumni and pals undeniably getting the best treatment (until they fall out of favor). A meritocracy MIIS is not. Faculty are pretty much treated like staff and have no real job security (unlike the vast majority of colleges and universities, professors at MIIS can't get tenure; they have to seek approval for contract renewal, which looks like a very arbitrary process). Competition for students has forced admissions to apply embarrassingly low standards. That it's so easy to get into a grad program at MIIS should be a source of shame (not that really dedicated and accomplished students don't earn their degrees here, but some graduates probably should never have been allowed to stay, let alone get degrees).

pros:
Great School and great people to work with.
Quiet environment to read and study while earning a little money.
Very flexible with scheduling and hours.
cons:
No benefits for part time graduate students.
I cannot think of any other cons at the moment but I do have a 20 word minimum.

review_title: Only for the tuition assistance benefit.
pros: Retirement and tuition assistance benefits are good. Some departments have balanced work home life expectations. Other departments pile on work as staff leave.
cons: Finance departments are significantly under staffed. Poor communications, definite air of superiority among management in some areas and retribution against staff.

pros: Excellent salary and benefits, great work/life balance. Nice community with a low crime rate. Excellent personal and professional growth opportunities offered through various venues such as Books 24/7 and Lynda.
cons: There are very few opportunities for advancement. Although it is good for the college that the employee turn over rate is low, for those staff members looking to move up it is difficult.

pros: Excellent Benefits, community involvement, access to what is needed to perform your job, communicative leadership, opportunity to build valuable life-long relationships.
cons: High expectations compromise work-life balance, unbalanced upper management makes the organization top heavy while staffing limitations make more work for operational staff

review_title: A great venue for like minded, international development professionals

cons: Facilities are sub par, library needs expansion and renovation, besides that it's a special place that the student often finds through experience

pros: You are allowed to learn as much as you want, as long as you put in the effort to do a good job.
